channel.title: jimgrisham tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from jimgrisham.

item.description:
@zahed @ulrichwi @HeinzDieterDetl Probably also depends to what extent the Soviets over-engineered their bridges, right?

(i.e. If they were extra-conservative with safety margins and careful in construction, it may hold up better than some of the ramshackle post-war construction in North America.)
item.source:markdown:
@zahed @ulrichwi @HeinzDieterDetl Probably also depends to what extent the Soviets over-engineered their bridges, right?
(i.e. If they were extra-conservative with safety margins and careful in construction, it may hold up better than some of the ramshackle post-war construction in North America.)

item.description:
@smallsoulbites @ericgarland If anyone is honestly interested in that:

https://t.co/ODENXDgKhj https://t.co/kAwEyeTWte

@smallsoulbites @ericgarland (Follow @TwitterSafety for more useful tips.)
@ColemanBess @SRuhle If you check the video closely, it appears there was an entire wall of ballistic glass between him and the crowd during the speech.
item.source:markdown: @ColemanBess @SRuhle If you check the video closely, it appears there was an entire wall of ballistic glass between him and the crowd during the speech.

item.description:
@luckystallard @carlbildt @Andy_Scollick There are constant #ISR flights over the Baltic sea and Romania.

Everything airborne is tracked and logged.

(There are also likely a non-zero number of intelligence imaging satellites tracking likely launch sites in the region.)

@luckystallard @carlbildt @Andy_Scollick (I meant to say “Black sea”, but the same is also mostly true for the Baltic, of course.)

@BenjaminEHowe @jeputz @sleepingdingo @marktavern @natecochrane @EpsonAmerica Depending on ones threat profile, that could be a ‘specific new feature’ to consider, if it promises to patch a specific vulnerability.

For a networked home printer behind a NAT router, or especially a non-networked USB model…
item.source:markdown:
@BenjaminEHowe @jeputz @sleepingdingo @marktavern @natecochrane @EpsonAmerica Depending on ones threat profile, that could be a ‘specific new feature’ to consider, if it promises to patch a specific vulnerability.
For a networked home printer behind a NAT router, or especially a non-networked USB model…

item.description:
@jeputz @sleepingdingo @marktavern @natecochrane @EpsonAmerica Brother is one of the better ones in this regard.

(Also, regardless of brand, it is best to avoid upgrading the firmware of cheap printers unless you’re trying to resolve a specific issue or are promised a specific new feature that is of value to you.)
item.source:markdown:
@jeputz @sleepingdingo @marktavern @natecochrane @EpsonAmerica Brother is one of the better ones in this regard.
(Also, regardless of brand, it is best to avoid upgrading the firmware of cheap printers unless you’re trying to resolve a specific issue or are promised a specific new feature that is of value to you.)

item.description:
@LeadershipNext1 @edwardstrngr ITER is currently scheduled for first plasma operations in next 40 months or so.

With additional funding and other support (such as rallying other scientists to contribute), that and the post-plasma timelines might be able to be quickened.

@iterorg

@CateBelling @melancholynsex @Enfamil @Walgreens Likely the physical cardboard box…

… normally the inside is printed with a color pattern (e.g. geometric, floral, or a just solid color), so if one carefully unfolds the box it can be flipped over and re-folded into an un-branded storage box (e.g. for scarves in a closet).
item.source:markdown:
@CateBelling @melancholynsex @Enfamil @Walgreens Likely the physical cardboard box…
… normally the inside is printed with a color pattern (e.g. geometric, floral, or a just solid color), so if one carefully unfolds the box it can be flipped over and re-folded into an un-branded storage box (e.g. for scarves in a closet).

item.description:
@sarahbeanz @robmorris123 @Pandora_HasABox @fiona_mugure Often that is because component-level parts and schematics are not furnished by the manufacturer.

Even now, (nearly?) every major appliance sold in the US (& for 70+ years), has a schematic hidden inside!

(The same was true for many TVs and radios for much of the past century.)

@sarahbeanz @robmorris123 @Pandora_HasABox @fiona_mugure If there was demand for repair (and parts availability), repair costs would drop with scale.

Many people may also feel more empowered to tinker and learn - even easier now with YouTube - in those down periods, such as after putting the kids to bed for the night.

#RightToRepair

@Curvycutie69 @DouglasNicol8 @natefernald Many old TVs (mostly CRTs and the first decade or so of some flat-panel plasma/LCD models) actually had room for the speakers to be on front, actually facing the room.

Sadly, it appears that ship has sailed.
item.source:markdown:
@Curvycutie69 @DouglasNicol8 @natefernald Many old TVs (mostly CRTs and the first decade or so of some flat-panel plasma/LCD models) actually had room for the speakers to be on ~front~, actually facing the room.
Sadly, it appears that ship has sailed.

item.description: @jtrebach Perhaps some day in the near future, a patient will be able to put on a pair of AR glasses in a pharmacy, say “exclude everything containing ‘X’, and have all those products disappear from view.
item.source:markdown: @jtrebach Perhaps some day in the near future, a patient will be able to put on a pair of AR glasses in a pharmacy, say “exclude everything containing ‘X’, and have all those products disappear from view.

item.description:
@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas Indeed.

Change should happen, and multiple strategies (in parallel) are probably in order.

We can investigate pricing/transparency and at the same time enlist everyone possible (in this case, young HCWs), to ease the transition to wherever we end up next.

@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas Agreed!

For something more straightforward, though, small decisions that have no measurable effect on outcomes, can have significant costs.

(e.g. brand vs. generic drug prescribing decisions in context of the loss of free t-shirts, lunches, and coffee mugs for fear of bias)

@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas Consider a stable patient that could justifiably be discharged from a hospital in the evening vs. the next morning.

The knowledge that 12 extra, unnecessary, hours as an inpatient might cost them hundreds or thousands of extra dollars probably should factor into that decision.

@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas Okay, I think y’all actually agree on most of this, then.

If you can know that MRIs are expensive, and therefore only order them judiciously… and also are cognizant of that, so you aren’t overly biased to avoid them…

… then we should teach all three of those, eh?

1/2

@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas It seemed @margaritaloxas was noting students aren’t taught how expensive many services/procedures can be, esp. when all of the ancillary charges are added up.

(There are examples in the replies about vastly unnecessary ambulance trips recommended in a perfunctory way.)

2/2
item.source:markdown:
@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas Okay, I think y’all actually agree on most of this, then.
If ~you~ can know that MRIs are expensive, and therefore only order them judiciously… and also are cognizant of that, so you aren’t overly biased to avoid them…
… then we should teach all three of those, eh?
1/2
@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas It seemed @margaritaloxas was noting students aren’t taught how expensive ~many~ services/procedures can be, esp. when all of the ancillary charges are added up.
(There are examples in the replies about _vastly_ unnecessary ambulance trips recommended in a perfunctory way.)
2/2

item.description:
@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas See also:

The moral results (in aggregate) of the 2010 passage of the #ACA, by generating massive political opposition and delaying the possibility of ‘single-payer’ or other universal insurance schemes for potentially decades, could go either way in the eye of history.
item.source:markdown:
@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas See also:
The moral results (in aggregate) of the 2010 passage of the #ACA, by generating massive political opposition and delaying the possibility of ‘single-payer’ or other universal insurance schemes for potentially _decades_, could go either way in the eye of history.

item.description: @DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas Perhaps in addition to encouraging this knowledge among HCWs, the ethics (and cognitive biases) of how to properly employ (or situationally how not to employ) that knowledge in various scenarios could also be taught, to head off those undesirable outcomes.
item.source:markdown: @DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas Perhaps in addition to encouraging this knowledge among HCWs, the ethics (and cognitive biases) of how to properly employ (or situationally how not to employ) that knowledge in various scenarios could also be taught, to head off those undesirable outcomes.

item.description:
@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas Everyone? No, of course not.

We can expect all new health care professionals to take on that task as part of their training, though.

Given that knowledge, they would then be in a better position to pass along that literacy to their patients, for decades.

@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas (… and perhaps facilitate better understanding of the motivations of those patients who may choose to forgo certain treatments.)

@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas Perhaps those resulting inequalities will be what it takes to rethink and reform health care funding?

If most people don’t realize the scale of the problem until their own family falls into medical debt, then most people won’t prioritize working/voting to fix the root causes.
item.source:markdown:
@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas Perhaps those resulting inequalities will be what it takes to rethink and reform health care funding?
If most people don’t realize the scale of the problem until _their own_ family falls into medical debt, then most people won’t prioritize working/voting to fix the root causes.

item.description:
@lrozen @lysa_modica It could actually be a bargaining chip to hasten a deal, to lower Russia’s resistance to restoring the #JCPOA …

… or a way for Iran to bilk money out of Russia, knowing the UAVs won’t arrive in enough time or quantity to change the outcome of the invasion.

Perhaps all three?

@SolitudinarianA @Misty_Melanie It’s hard not to ‘miss intent’ when that intent conflicts with logic (e.g. consistency with past statements), and the plain meaning of language.

Communication is a two-way street, and any failed communication (even if one party is ‘neuro-atypical’) indicates both sides can grow.

@SolitudinarianA @Misty_Melanie Tl;dr: it’s not (all) you; it’s them too!

@Dennis_Ramen @FemiYahtzee It is:

  1. hard (logistically speaking, to do at scale - i.e. each district needs to decide to take action, then decide what action to take, then hire/manage contractors)

  2. unlike post-9/11 security, not backed by lobbyists and high-margin consultants

See also: infrastructure

@Dennis_Ramen @FemiYahtzee To be clear, that wasn’t meant to excuse anyone… rather:

The first step in conquering many problems, much like when defeating witches, is naming them.

@Dennis_Ramen @FemiYahtzee #NotAllWitches
@dima7b @compodeth @Osinttechnical The profits from them also are likely helping fund the invasion?
item.source:markdown: @dima7b @compodeth @Osinttechnical The profits from them also are likely helping fund the invasion?
